items.title: Birders flock to Vancouver beach to see rare bird native to Russia
items.summary_auto: Dozens of birders descended on Vancouver’s Sunset Beach Park on Sunday to catch a rare glimpse of a bird that avian enthusiasts say has never been recorded in Canada before.

items.title: Pilot killed, another injured after helicopters collide midair in New Jersey, officials say
items.summary_auto: The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) described the crash as a midair collision between an Enstrom F-28A helicopter and Enstrom 280C helicopter over Hammonton Municipal Airport. Only the pilots were on board each aircraft.

items.title: Halifax video game workers form first Ubisoft union in North America
items.summary_auto: About 60 workers in Halifax office voted in favour of unionizing amid concerns about AI and industry-wide layoffs.

items.title: Public opinion divided on return-to-office mandates
items.summary_auto: The debate on where work should happen – remote or in office – is far from over. Linda Duxbury, a professor at Carleton University's Sprott School of Business, explains.

items.title: Saint John woman recovering after moose kicked her in the head during collision with car
items.summary_auto: Family of Courtney Deveau, 28, says her recovery from traumatic brain injury may take months.

items.title: Canadian food banks record over 4 million visits this year
items.summary_auto: The Daily Bread Food Bank in Toronto is seeing a spike in young adults, between the ages of 19 and 44, in need of a food bank. The CBC speaks with the food bank’s CEO, Neil Hetherington.

items.title: Blue Jays named The Canadian Press team of the year after deep playoff run
items.summary_auto: The Blue Jays completed a worst-to-first turnaround and rode the momentum into a memorable post-season that saw them go all the way to Game 7 of the World Series.

items.title: Toronto under rainfall warning, Environment Canada says
items.summary_auto: Toronto could see between 20 and 40 millimetres of rain Sunday afternoon, Environment Canada says.

items.title: Brigitte Bardot, icon of French cinema turned animal rights activist, dead at 91
items.summary_auto: Brigitte Bardot, the French 1960s actress who became one of the greatest screen sirens of the 20th century and later an animal rights activist and far-right supporter, has died. She was 91.

items.title: Does investing locally matter to Canadians amid tariff war?
items.summary_auto: A Vancouver-based company hopes Canadians look to keep some of their investment dollars local and create an impact — even as the trend of investment dollars flowing south of the border looks set to continue into 2026.

items.title: 2 dead, 3 people taken to hospital after Charlottetown apartment fire
items.summary_auto: Two people are dead and three people have been taken to hospital after an early morning fire at a Charlottetown apartment building. The condition of the three people taken to hospital is unclear.

items.title: Wintry weather warnings issued for parts of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick
items.summary_auto: Environment Canada has issued  yellow warnings  for wintry conditions in parts of Nova Scotia and New Brunswick.

items.title: Empty pews: Rural Manitoba churches struggle to find ministers
items.summary_auto: Rural United Church of Canada congregations as they struggle to find ministers. In the Prairie to Pine region in Manitoba and Northern Ontario minister vacancies can reach 63 per cent. Rev. Doug Neufeld serves two churches in southwestern Manitoba but is leaving for Ontario, his will make him hard to replace.

items.title: Before robbing trains in the States, the Sundance Kid was a cowboy in Alberta
items.summary_auto: Harry Longabaugh — better known as the Sundance Kid — is perhaps most famous for his daring bank and train robberies as part of Butch Cassidy’s Wild Bunch. But the American outlaw’s short stint as a cowboy and businessman in southern Alberta is a lesser-known chapter of Wild West history.

items.title: In 2025, melting sea ice allowed a Canadian icebreaker to enter the world's last ice area
items.summary_auto: Often referred to as the one of the last places in the world with year-round sea ice, the waterways around Queen Elizabeth Islands and western Tuvaijuittuq have historically been difficult to access. But in 2025, melting sea ice opened a path for a Canadian research icebreaker to sail through this part of the country for the first time ever.

items.title: Invasive snail species found in P.E.I. believed to be new to the Maritime provinces
items.summary_auto: The species appears to be an invasive snail known as the big-eared radix, which is native to Europe and Asia. It was found in Andrew's Pond in the East Royalty area of Charlottetown.

items.title: Saving the petrel: Volunteers keep moving with patrol to save stranded sea birds
items.summary_auto: Picking up petrels has become another part of fall for some folks along the eastern coast of Newfoundland.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Highlights from Toronto's 2025
items.summary_auto: CBC News photographer Evan Mitsui captured the Toronto Blue Jays' epic season, plus other notable events in Toronto and the GTA during the year.

items.title: This Toronto long-term care home is being redesigned after learning from the COVID-19 pandemic
items.summary_auto: A downtown Toronto long-term care home is rebuilding with a new design that considers lessons learned from the COVID-19 pandemic, going beyond the province’s standards — but some say those standards are out of date.
